99% of businesses have absolutely no idea how to analyse their competitors. 
 
Here’s an overpowered tactic I actually use: 
 
Let’s say I want an inside scoop on the current strategy of a competitor, new market entrant, interesting brand etc. 
 
Their landing page, about page and product page all tell me ‘𝙝𝙤𝙬 the brand positions itself’. 
 
But an interesting data point you can go after is ‘𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 the brand positions itself’. 
 
Chatspot is a free AI app developed as a side-project by Dharmesh Shah (founder of HubSpot). 
 
If I ask it “What keywords does [company] buy?”, it tells me: 
 
· Which keywords the company is buying 
· Where they rank for those keywords 
· What the keyword search volume is 
· What the cost-per-click is 
 
The keywords, rankings, volume, and CPCs, tell me: 
 
· Which competitors they are targeting 
· Which traffic they are stealing 
· Which trends they are riding 
· Which niches they value 
 
X-Ray vision for anyone working in areas like strategy, product, or marketing.

Ever wondered why Google, one of Apple's primary competitors, is the default search engine on Safari, iOS, and MacOS? 
 
Well, they pay Apple an enormous yearly sum: 
 
In 2021, they forked over $15 billion. 
 
Last year, around $20 billion. 
 
This year, likely even more. 
 
Straight profit for Apple. 
 
In fact, over the last few years the payment has accounted for 14-21% of Apple's annual profits (!) 
 
It's the single biggest payment Google makes to anyone... for anything. 
 
The only catch? In exchange for the payment, Apple agreed not to develop it's own search engine. 
 
Could you imagine a world in which Microsoft outbids Google, and the default search engine becomes Bing?

This controversial email from Mark Zuckerberg to Facebook execs got leaked.  
  
Here's everything you need to know:  
  
Facebook established a secret internal operation with the aim of understanding how its users were interacting with its competitors.  
  
Named "Project Ghostbusters", with reference to Snapchat’s ghost-like logo, Facebook wanted to figure out a way to analyse encrypted app traffic from users of Snapchat.  
  
Facebook installed so-called 'kits' (using Onavo, a VPN-like service that Facebook acquired in 2013) on its users iOS and Android devices, which allowed Facebook to read network traffic before it got encrypted and sent to Snapchat's servers.  
  
Facebook expanded the tactic, commonly called a "man-in-the-middle attack", to Amazon and YouTube.  
  
Not all execs agreed that "Project Ghostbusters" was a good idea.  
  
In another leaked email exchange, Pedro Canahuati, then-head of security engineering said: "I can’t think of a good argument for why this is okay. No security person is ever comfortable with this, no matter what consent we get from the general public. The general public just doesn’t know how this stuff works.”  
  
Wild! 👀

Sheryl Sandberg emails Google exec about Facebook poaching their top employees

This is Arianna Huffington.

She’s written 15 books, founded and sold The Huffington Post for $315 million, and is building a health-tech platform valued over $700 million.

Here are 12 of her most powerful lessons on fear, success, and mindset:

𝗢𝗻 𝗳𝗲𝗮𝗿:

1. Failure is not the opposite of success; it’s part of success.

2. Fearlessness is not the absence of fear. It’s the mastery of fear. It’s about getting up one more time than we fall down.

3. The fastest way to break the cycle of perfectionism and become fearless is to give up the idea of doing it perfectly – indeed to embrace uncertainty and imperfection.

𝗢𝗻 𝘀𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀:

4. Success is commonly defined as money and power, but increasingly that’s not enough. It’s almost like a two-legged stool where you fall over if that’s all you measure your life by.

5. We need to accept that we won’t always make the right decisions, that we’ll screw up royally sometimes – understanding that failure is not the opposite of success, it’s part of success.

6. We don’t need more to be successful. We need less – less clutter, less noise, less distraction.

7. Thrive means not just surviving, but flourishing as a human being – emotionally, physically, spiritually, and professionally.

𝗢𝗻 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱𝘀𝗲𝘁:

8. The only way to create a singularly unique product or point of view is to do the inner work to unearth it.

9. In today’s world, with so much noise, information and stress competing for our attention, mindfulness isn’t a luxury, it’s a necessity

10. Disconnecting from our technology to reconnect with ourselves is absolutely essential for wisdom

11. If you have the ability to inspire others, it’s your duty to do so. Inspiration isn’t something that happens by accident or luck – it’s a responsibility that we all have towards each other.

12. It’s not about having time; it’s about making time. Time is precious and finite, and we can’t afford to waste a single moment pursuing anything but our highest priorities

At an executive retreat at Jeff Bezos’ house in 2003, Amazon leadership ran an exercise that changed the course of history forever.  
 
The exercise started with a discussion about Amazon's core competencies: 
 
→ Offering a broad selection of products?  
→ Check. 
 
→ Fulfilling and shipping orders?  
→ Nailing it. 
 
A few rotations later, they discussed IT. 
 
As a rapidly-scaling low-margin retail business, they had been forced to become market-leaders in running reliable and cost-effective state-of-the-art data centres. 
 
This little nugget presented an opportunity:  
 
In 1900, a business had to build a generator to open a shop, so why should a business in 2000 have to build its own datacenter? 
 
Over the next few years, Amazon folded its highly-desirable architecture inside-out, offering compute, databases, and storage to the market under the banner ‘Amazon Web Services’. 
 
The result? 
 
Today AWS services 41.5% (!!) of all web application workloads. 
 
While it accounts for 13% of $AMZN’s revenue, it pulls in nearly 75% of the company’s operating profit.

The ‘Humble Brag’ can be a powerful ad framework, IF you do it right:

1. The brag is legit: If you’re trying too hard to flex, it shows. Avoid ‘cringe’ at all costs.
2. IYKYK: You only ‘get’ the brag if you ‘get’ the ad. Smart ads make the audience feel smart.
3. Sarcasm wins: Self-aware, tongue-in-cheeky humility beats obvious self-promotion.

Quiet confidence is the loudest.

If I had to make a playbook for predictable growth, it would start with these metrics. 

From MRR to NPS, this cheat sheet provides a baseline for key SaaS metrics you should be tracking. 

𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘄𝘁𝗵 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀:
• 𝗠𝗥𝗥: Your subscription revenue heartbeat.
• 𝗔𝗥𝗥: Forecasted yearly revenue based on monthly performance
• 𝗖𝗔𝗖: Cost of acquiring new customers.
• 𝗟𝗧𝗩: Average customer's lifetime value.
• 𝗖𝗠𝗚𝗥: Normalised month-over-month growth rate.
• 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗠𝗥𝗥: Additional revenue from existing customers.

𝗥𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀:
• 𝗗𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗿 𝗥𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: Ongoing revenue generation within a cohort.
• 𝗖𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿 𝗥𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Track the proportion of retained customers.
• 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗿𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Subscription cancellations.
• 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Reduction in subscription spend.
• 𝗡𝗣𝗦: Customer likelihood to recommend your business.
• 𝗖𝗦𝗔𝗧: Customer satisfaction levels.

𝗦𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀:
• 𝗔𝗻𝗻𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁 𝗩𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲: Average annualised revenue per contract.
• 𝗔𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗦𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗖𝘆𝗰𝗹𝗲 𝗟𝗲𝗻𝗴𝘁𝗵: Time taken for leads to convert.
• 𝗪𝗶𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Deal success against opportunities.
• 𝗠𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗡𝘂𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿: Efficiency of Net New ARR compared to expenses.
• 𝗤𝘂𝗼𝘁𝗮 𝗔𝘁𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Assess sales teams' performance against targets.
• 𝗔𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗗𝗲𝗮𝗹 𝗦𝗶𝘇𝗲: Average value of each closed deal.

• 𝗪𝗶𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Deal success against opportunities.
• 𝗠𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗡𝘂𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿: Efficiency of Net New ARR compared to expenses.
• 𝗤𝘂𝗼𝘁𝗮 𝗔𝘁𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Assess sales teams' performance against targets.
• 𝗔𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗗𝗲𝗮𝗹 𝗦𝗶𝘇𝗲: Average value of each closed deal.

𝗘𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀:
• 𝗗𝗔𝗨: Track daily active users engaging with your product.
• 𝗠𝗔𝗨: Track monthly active users engaging with your product.
• 𝗗𝗔𝗨/𝗠𝗔𝗨: Ensure a healthy product usage ratio.
• 𝗣𝗮𝗶𝗱 𝗦𝗲𝗮𝘁𝘀 𝗣𝗲𝗿 𝗖𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿: Average user licences per paid account.
• 𝗙𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗧𝗼 𝗣𝗮𝗶𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Measure conversion of free users to paid.
• 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀: Key actions during trial periods for enhanced conversion.

This is just a starting point. You must always add other metrics depending on your business model, objectives, and market.

💬 What other metrics would you track?

Steve Jobs had a simple rule for designing the perfect user interface: 
 
The 3-click rule. 
 
Steve was intimately involved in the design and development of the original iPod. 
 
Those that knew him said he had the same response to nearly every problem - 
 
“Simplify!” 
 
During product demos, he would go over every screen and apply a rigid test: 
 
If a user wants to use a core feature (eg play a song) ... 
 
they must be able to get there in three clicks. 
 
The success of the iPod changed the industry forever, and the 3-click rule quickly spread across product development circles. 
 
Airbnb founder Brian Chesky was always adamant users are never more than 3 clicks away from a booking. 
 
Same as reading trending content from your favourite subreddit. 
 
Or watching your favourite Youtuber’s latest video. 
 
If you're building a consumer product, ask yourself: 
 
How many clicks does it take for a user to reach your unique-selling-point?

AI NEWS: Miro just redesigned their entire product around AI.

70+ million users. 99 of the Fortune 100 as customers. Now with virtual AI teammates - living inside their daily workspace.

Here’s everything you need to know:

I was given early access to ‘Intelligent Canvas’ - a major platform update revolving around AI workflows, board customisation, and intelligent integrations, all with the aim of radically speeding up the product development lifecycle.

They’ve dissected the specific tasks performed in critical business processes like sprint planning, journey mapping, and roadmapping, and worked backwards from the question:
“How can we empower teams with AI superpowers and teammates to get more done, in less time?”

Here’s a few (sci-fi-like) features they’re rolling out over the next few months:

🤖 AI sidekicks:
Drop virtual agents with expert skillsets (like ‘Product Leader’ or ‘Agile Coach’) into any collaboration session to ask them for inputs, get feedback on the work, or synthesisee their findings on the conversation so far.

🎨 Create with AI:
Generate things like feature ideas, workflow diagrams, or marketing imagery during your real-time collaborations, based on everything Miro knows about your project or product.

🧠 Synthesise with AI:
Instantly turn your sprawling stickies, polls, and notes into a structured document format (think PRDs, roadmaps, research reports etc). No prompting needed - the canvas is the prompt.

🔗 Intelligent Widgets:
AI-suggested integrations (Jira issue backlog) and tools (story points) that let teams jump straight into the work rather than wasting time on setup and configuration.

🔄 AI shortcuts:
Everyone has manual workflows they always perform after certain meetings (summarise 1:1 meeting notes, synthesise retrospective findings)? Now you can add ‘AI shortcuts’ directly into the board to perform that task with 1-click.

💬 Link in the comments!

--

I personally love this strategic direction. Lots of AI features I’m seeing these days feel like a gimmick. They ‘accelerate’ an activity that isn’t actually valuable/necessary.

It’s immediately obvious from inside the product that everyone over at Miro HQ has exercised real restraint: they’ve only used AI in ways that are actually going to save users time.

Props!

#miro #canvas24 #miroAI

DoorDash pulled off one of the most underappreciated market share robberies of all time.

In just 3 years, they exploded from 16% to 53% share of the US delivery app market.

Here’s 4 strategies they used to crush Uber Eats, GrubHub and Postmates:

1. Avoiding the competition

DoorDash targeted restaurants without delivery services, often with pre-existing customer bases, rather than competing for newer restaurants with multiple other providers.

2. Empowering restaurants

DoorDash acquired restaurants by providing them with not just delivery services, but insights they never had before: popular dishes in the area, customer demographics, local delivery times, and more.

3. Maximising AOV

DoorDash focussed on winning outer suburbs with large family homes - an underserved segment with a much higher average-order-value (AOV) than urban regions.

4. Brand positioning

When Covid hit, DoorDash supported its Dashers and restaurants by offering payment advances and other benefits, creating significant supply growth for their marketplace.

Doordash saw the opportunity, developed a plan... and they delivered.

How Airbnb generated users on autopilot back in 2008. 
 
Airbnb knew that Craigslist had a massive user base actively seeking rentals. 
 
In order to generate more impressions (and improve completion rate) on Airbnb listings, they constructed a seamless flow for hosts to cross-post their listings to Craigslist. 
 
When users posted on Airbnb, they were given the option to “post to Craigslist”, which generated a pre-filled listing template. 
 
Under the hood, the bot:  
→ visited Craigslist  
→ filled in some forms  
→ opened a draft listing  
→ created an HTML template  
→ copied the unique URL string 
→ returned it to the user for publishing 
 
To make the flow as frictionless as possible, the bot automatically added a compelling title, detailed description, category, location, high-quality images, and crucially - a direct link back to the listing on Airbnb’s website. 
 
By equipping hosts with tools to broadcast their rentals, Airbnb tapped into Craigslist’s vast traffic base, funnelling new users back to their own site.

Snapchat is one of the most fascinating tech acquirers of all time.

When you break it down, their entire business is an amalgamation of acquired startups.

Here are the 25 deals that shaped the Snapchat of today:

1. AddLive (2014) - $30m
Became Snapchats ‘Video Chat’ feature.

2. Vergence Labs (2014) - $15m
Became ‘Spectacles’, Snapchat’s smart glasses hardware line.

3. Scan me (2014) - $50m
Became ‘Snapcodes’, Snapchat’s personalised QR code feature.

4. Looksery (2015) - $150m
Became ‘Filters’ and ‘Lenses’, Snapchat’s facial recognition and modification technology.

5. Bitstrips (2016) - $100m
Became ‘Bitmojis’, Snapchat’s personalised avatars.

6. Seene (2016) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s ‘3D Selfies’, powering face swaps and other AR overlays.

7. Vurb (2016) - $114.5m
Became Snapchat’s local business search and discovery features.

8. Flite (2016) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s tech powering 360° video ads and vertical video ads.

9. Cimagine (2016) - $30-40m
Became Snapchat’s AR product visualisation features.

10. Ctrl Me Robotics (2017) - <$1m
Became part of Snapchat’s hardware team.

11. Placed (2017) - $135m
Became Snapchat’s ad tracking for foot traffic and conversions in physical stores.

12. Zenly (2017) - $213m
Became ‘Snap Map’, Snapchat’s interactive social maps.

13. Strong Codes (2017) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s code protection technology.

14. Metamarkets (2017) - $100m
Became Snapchat’s analytics dashboard for advertisers.

15. PlayCanvas (2018) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s ‘Lens Studio’, where developers build AR Lens effects.

16. Teleport (2018) - $8m
Became part of Snapchat’s ‘Filters’ technology, powering features like hair colour changes.

17. AIFactory (2020) - $166m
Became ‘Cameos’, Snapchat’s animated selfie video feature.

18. Voca ai (2020) - $70m
Became Snapchat’s Ai-based voice agents for customer support.

19. Voisey (2020) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s music creation and sharing features.

20. Ariel AI (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s AR experiences team.

21. Fit Analytics (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s virtual clothing try-on and sizing features.

22. Screenshop (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s product recommendations based on images saved to ‘Memories’.

23. Demand Sage (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s ad reporting and analytics features.

24. Pixel8earth (2021) - $7.6m
Became part of ‘Local Lenses’, Snapchat’s location-based AR experiences.

25. WaveOptics (2021) - $500m
Became Snapchat’s AR display manufacturing team.

One of the experiments that’s working well is interviews. The ‘interview’ is a timeless content format that allows us to resolve speculations through stories.

But interviews also come with downsides, from the perspective of the reader:

𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗲𝘅𝘁: If you don’t have context on the company the interviewee represents, it’s likely to be less valuable.

𝗤𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀: The success of the interview depends on the calibre of the questions. As a reader you don’t get to ask the specific questions you’d most like to hear the interviewee answer.

𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝘁: The best video and audio conversations make you feel like a ‘fly-on-the-wall’ to a moment you wouldn’t otherwise experience. That feeling doesn’t translate well to written interviews.

North Star Metrics 101

My Mum texted me asking, “what exactly is a North Star Metric?”

Here’s what I sent her:

So you’ve built a product, and people are using it.

You start tracking everything you can to measure how well the product is performing:

- Daily/Weekly/Monthly Active Users
- Customer Acquisition Cost
- Customer growth rate
- Net expansion rate
- Conversion rate
- Feature usage
- Lifetime value
- Contraction
- Retention
- Drop-off

Invariably, you run into the same problem:

You want all key metrics to go up, but you’re not sure which ones to prioritise investing in.

The answer?

The North Star Metric: A single metric that defines success for your business.

“Wouldn’t that just be revenue?”

Although it’s tempting to always default to financial KPIs, the best North Star Metrics help businesses understand how customers truly derive value from their product.

Put simply - the more you drive your North Star, the more 𝙫𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙚 your business creates.

SEO 101: 
 
 
People looking to design something don’t search for an ‘all-in-one design solution’. 
 
They start a business, decide they need a logo, and search ‘Logo Maker’. 
 
A few sales meetings later, they search ‘Free Business Card Maker’. 
 
Canva, maker of the world’s favourite ‘all-in-one design solution’, knows this. 
 
So - they built hundreds of landing pages for specific design tools that prospects are actively searching for. 
 
Unlike their front page, which is probably swamped with low-intent evaluators, Canva’s utility-focussed lead magnets capture highly convertible leads wanting to land in-product as quickly as possible. 
 
Throughout the journey, users are subtle introduced to the universe of premium design possibilities available on the platform. 
 
Enticing tooltips, gated features, teamwork capabilities, and free AI credits all systematically funnel free users towards the paid offering. 
 
Canva’s strategy in one line: 
 
“Make stuff people search for” — Harry Dry

Square co-founder Jim McKelvey built their first card-reader prototype by hand.

A timeless lesson in thinking outside the box:

Back in 2010, the only approved way to connect any piece of hardware to an iPhone was through the dock connector.

Apple had a lengthy and expensive approval process to use the connector, special chipsets you had to use, royalties on each unit, and many other restrictions.

On the other hand, every phone on the market, not just the iPhone, had a microphone jack.

But the jack was only designed to take an audio signal.

Jim knew that the audio software developer kit was part of the public iPhone libraries and therefore didn’t need Apple’s permission to use.

He and co-founder Jack Dorsey devised a way to make the data on a credit card stripe appear to be the output of a microphone.

By using the microphone jack to circumvent Apple’s dock connector rules, they had a working prototype in a week.

The takeaway here?

When building your MVP, it’s better to ask for forgiveness than permission!

Patrick Collison created $50 billion of value as a co-founder of Stripe.

He has also built the largest carbon removal program in the world.

𝗔𝘁 𝟯𝟱 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀 𝗼𝗹𝗱, 𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝟭𝟱 𝗽𝗶𝗲𝗰𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝗵𝗲’𝗱 𝗴𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗽𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘀𝗲𝗹𝗳: 
(From his personal blog, in a post titled “Advice”)

1. Go deep on things. Become an expert.

2. In particular, try to go deep on 𝘮𝘶𝘭𝘵𝘪𝘱𝘭𝘦 things. One of the main things you should try to achieve by age 20 is some sense for which kinds of things you 𝘦𝘯𝘫𝘰𝘺 doing. 

3. Don't stress out too much about how valuable the things you're going deep on are... but don't ignore it either. It should be a factor you weigh but not by itself dispositive.

4. To the extent that you enjoy working hard, do. Subject to that constraint, it's not clear that the returns to effort ever diminish substantially.

5. Make friends over the internet with people who are great at things you're interested in. The internet is one of the biggest advantages you have over prior generations. Leverage it.

6. Aim to read a lot.

7. If you think something is important but people older than you don't hold it in high regard, there's a reasonable chance that you're right and they're wrong. Status lags by a generation or more.

8. Above all else, don't make the mistake of judging your success based on your current peer group. By all means make friends but being weird as a teenager is generally good.

9. 𝘉𝘶𝘵 having good social skills confers life-long benefits. So, don't write them off. Get good at making a good first impression, being funny, speaking publicly.

10. Make things. Operating in a space with a lot of uncertainty is a very different experience to learning something.

11. More broadly, nobody is going to teach you to think for yourself. A large fraction of what people around you believe is mistaken. Internalize this and practice coming up with your own worldview.

12. If you're in the US and go to a good school, there are a lot of forces that will push you towards following train-tracks laid by others rather than charting a course yourself. 

13. Figure out a way to travel to San Francisco and to meet other people who've moved there to pursue their dreams.

14. Find vivid examples of success in the domains you care about. If you want to become a great scientist, try to find ways to spend time with good (or, ideally, great) scientists in person.

15. People who did great things often did so at very surprisingly young ages. So, hurry up! You can do great things.

This maths teacher from rural Australia sold his tech company for $40m.

From bootstrapped side hustle to life-changing exit.

Here is Andrew Spitty’s incredible story:

In 2011, Andrew was teaching at Kerang Technical High School in a small town in country Victoria.

Frustrated by inconsistencies in how students were assessed across schools, he saw an opportunity:

Provide schools with a standardised set of numeracy and literacy assessments, and software that tracks how well students and schools perform.

He launched ‘Essential Assessment’ in 2012 as a side hustle.

Besides contracting his brother Troy to build the basic website and solution, Andrew was a solo operator for the first 4 years.

Working as the only salesperson, customer service, marketer, business manager, content developer (and a full-time maths teacher) he grew his customer-base to over 500 schools (!!)

In 2015, Andrew had proven his business had momentum to scale, and decided to go all-in.

He brought his brother on full-time, scaled the company to 22 employees, and expanded to over 2500 schools in the next 7 years.

Today, more than a third of primary schools in Victoria and NSW use Essential Assessment to assess student performance and improve achievement.

So, how did the acquisition come about?

New Zealand-based ‘Education Perfect’, a digital teaching and learning toolkit for schools, saw a natural strategic alignment between the two companies.

“Essential Assessment is incredibly strong in primary schools, while we are absolutely the market leader in middle school and moving into senior, and we saw this wonderful fit ... also in culture, with a very strong focus on teachers” — Helen Souness, chair of Education Perfect’s board.

From a product synergy perspective, the partnership also showed great potential: “Three key things for us is that we’re saving teachers time, we are able to assess students and give insights on their progress, and then use that to give personalised learning pathways.”

When it’s all said and done, Andrew Smitty will walk away from this deal with ~$40m in cash.

100% shareholder. No outside investment. Profitable since year 1. Fully bootstrapped.

In 2006, Netflix offered $1 million to anyone who could beat their recommendation algorithm. This is the story of 'The Netflix Prize':

Netflix’s entire business rides on its personalisation algorithm.

80% of content their users watch is recommended to them by Netflix.

Their recommendation engine is so efficient at preventing user abandonment, Netflix believes it saves them more than $1 billion per year.

But how did they develop such a powerful algorithm?

In the early days, they came up with a novel strategy involving nothing more than a good ol’ fashioned $1 million prize pool...

In 2006, Netflix announced they would pay $1 million to anyone in the world who could improve their recommendation algorithm by 10%.

Netflix open-sourced a dataset of user ratings and asked participants to predict how those users would rate movies they hadn't seen yet.

Thousands of teams tackled the problem, sharing their results and algorithms along the way.

After 3 years, a group of Austrian, Canadian, American, and Israeli hackers called “Bellkor's Pragmatic Chaos” developed a solution verified to be a 10.05% improvement, and took home the grand prize.

The genius of this strategy is the way it plays into human psychology: by aligning competitive incentives, the ‘Netflix Prize’ was a faster, cheaper, and less risky alternative to in-house research and development.

For the hackers working on the problem, $1m created the allure of a windfall gain.

Netflix made it no secret that to them the $1m was a colossal bargain for a landmark product enhancement.

A public leaderboard added fuel to the fire by creating visibility between the progress of contestants.

If no solution was found, Netflix didn’t spend a penny (on the cash prize or in time-invested).

The ‘Netflix Prize’ still stands as one of history's best best win-win-win scenarios:

Hackers won a million bucks. 

Users won better recommendations. 

Netflix won an even bigger moat for their best-in-class product.

The original plan was to stop after 1 month 🤦‍♂️  
  
Here's 3 takeaways from those early days:  
  
1. Getting "1% better" each post really does work.  
  
➔ I spent way too much time researching growth strategy, how to go viral, best time to post, when to comment etc. all before I even started writing! It turns out, the only way to put out high-quality and platform-optimised content is to start posting and improve a single aspect each day.  
  
2. The best growth hack is simply to not stop.  
  
➔ A regular cadence doesn't just ensure you maximise your exposure in the feed, it also helps you to form a daily writing habit. Generally speaking, people at 20k followers haven't figured something out that people at 5k haven't - they just haven't stopped posting!  
  
3. Being great is just being good repeatedly  
  
➔ If you look at any of the largest creators on the platform - the one thing they all have in common is consistency. Sure they have adopted tactics, leveraged networks, and gone viral along the way, but it's the sheer volume of content that allows them to iterate and compound their way to success.  
  
If you're writing online -  
this is a friendly reminder to keep going.

Payal Kadakia sold her 8-year old company for over $1 billion.

From the daughter of Indian immigrants to startup icon, here is Payal's incredible story.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝗮𝗿𝗹𝘆 𝗬𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀:

Her parents, who had moved from India to New Jersey, placed a huge emphasis on providing Payal with a complete education. 

She grew up in the #1 rated school district, and her early life revolved around dance, fitness, and a love for math and science.

In 2011, with a degree from MIT, Payal started her career at Bain Consulting and Warner Music. 

She quickly grew tired of corporate life and gave herself 14 days to come up with an idea for her own company.

Inspired by her friends building online platforms in the mobile app goldrush, she envisioned a solution to a personal pain point - difficulty booking dance classes. 

The idea for ClassPass was born.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗽𝘁:

ClassPass iterated through a number of business model concepts:

→ A search engine for fitness classes.

The discovery process wasn’t a sticky enough problem for users - rather they had issues committing to to a healthy lifestyle change. 

→ A Groupon-style package of 10 classes for $49.

Started generating revenue, but wasn't sustainable because users weren’t going back to purchase a studio membership. Studios were giving away 10 classes for free, but users weren't converting afterwards.

→ A 10-class subscription for $99 per month.

The ongoing commitment kept users accountable, and the variety of classes had them hooked on the app. 

Product-market-fit.

Fast forward 4 years, and ClassPass had booked over 17 million fitness classes. 

A year later, 35 million reservations, and an aggressive expansion across the US. 

Years of trial and error was only possible for someone truly obsessed with the problem space from a young age:
• She would miss night outs to go dancing
• She left her last performance review early to go to dancing practice
• She started a dance studio, "The Sa Dance Company" (where she still performs to this day!)

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗰𝗾𝘂𝗶𝘀𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻:

In 2021 ClassPass was acquired by Mindbody, the leading booking engine for fitness classes. 

Mindbody helps users book local fitness options, but didn't offer the multi-vendor bundles that ClassPass thrived on. 

No pricing terms of the all-stock deal were disclosed, but it was reported that:
• Mindbody would hold between a 60%-70% of the combined entity.
• ClassPass was valued "significantly" above $1 billion.

Today, Payal is a successful author, an impactful advocate for female entrepreneurship, and the artistic director of 'The Sa Dance Company'.

Tracy Young sold her 7-year old startup for $875m.

From humble beginnings as the daughter of Vietnamese refugees to a Silicon Valley icon.

Here’s her incredible story:

Young’s parent’s fled Vietnam after the war, leaving on a fishing boat with hundreds of others.

After a temporary stay in Malaysia, her family was sponsored by a Lutheran priest to live in a church in California.

Even without speaking the language, Young’s parents worked a number of odd jobs and eventually started a wholesale food supply business.

Fast forward to 2011, they had put all 3 children through college, and Young was working as a construction engineer.

Frustrated by an industry that operated on paper, she was uniquely positioned to notice a business opportunity involving Apple’s latest innovation:

The iPad.

At the time, paper-based building plans were brought onto building sites, reprinted constantly, and worked on by many collaborators.

This was expensive, inefficient, and a headache for construction teams.

Young saw a gap in the market and started PlanGrid - a suite of mobile-optimised, cloud-based tools for digital construction blueprints.

To give you a sense of the founding team’s grit, urgency, and willpower, here’s 2 awesome stories from their early days:

1. Serving customers no matter what

In order to get their product in the hands of customers, Young had to buy as many iPads as possible.

At the time, Apple limited the number of tablets you could buy at a time.

Young and her team wore disguises and maxed out their credit cards to procure enough devices to load up with their software for their early customers.

2. Force-feeding product adoption

Young’s team knew construction conferences were a value-dense market to attack, but renting a booth cost over $5,000.

Instead, they bought $60 tickets and went up to strangers saying, “Hey, wanna see something cool?”

Whether they answered or not, they’d run the demo.

To this day, 2 of PlanGrid’s top 10 customers are from those early conference efforts.

Over the next 7 years, Young scaled PlanGrid so flawlessly that their story is now considered the Silicon Valley playbook to crack big, established industries.

Boiling the playbook down to a few key pages:
• Call every single lead.
• Prioritise predictable growth.
• All staff can demo the product.
• Get the product in customers hands.
• Attack core B2B personas and expand.

In 2018, PlanGrid was acquired by AutoDesk for a whopping $875m.

Today, Young runs TigerEye, software that tracks and predicts future performance of sales teams.

She also runs a newsletter coined “Predictable Growth” where she interviews female leaders driving revenue for their businesses.

3x cognitive biases Apple uses to make you spend more:

Let's say you want to buy an iPad. 

You open the Apple website, and you're presented with 5x options:

𝟭. $𝟯𝟮𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝟵𝘁𝗵 𝗚𝗲𝗻): The most affordable iPad.
𝟮. $𝟰𝟰𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝟭𝟬𝘁𝗵 𝗚𝗲𝗻): The newer iPad with a better display, chip, camera, and USB-C.
𝟯. $𝟰𝟵𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝗠𝗶𝗻𝗶): The compact iPad that fits in one hand. 
𝟰. $𝟱𝟵𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝗔𝗶𝗿): The thinner and lighter iPad with a laptop-grade chip. 
𝟱. $𝟳𝟵𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝗣𝗿𝗼): The best iPad money can buy.

Like most prospective customers, your needs would be met with the cheapest iPad on offer...

but you end up spending an additional 82% (+$270) on the iPad Air. 

Why is that?

The answer begins with the
👉 “𝗖𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿-𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗘𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁” 👈

When customers are presented with a range of choices, they perceive the middle options to be the 𝘣𝘦𝘴𝘵 𝘷𝘢𝘭𝘶𝘦-𝘧𝘰𝘳-𝘮𝘰𝘯𝘦𝘺.

Most buyers don’t consider themselves a 𝘱𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳-𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 needing a ‘Pro’ device.

But there’s also natural aversion to buying a 𝘱𝘳𝘦𝘷𝘪𝘰𝘶𝘴-𝘨𝘦𝘯 device.

Due to the 👉 “𝗖𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿-𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗘𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁” 👈, you’re likely to initiate your purchase flow with the base 10th Gen iPad.

After choosing a colour, you’re asked to “Choose how much space you’ll need”:
64GB or 256GB.

For 4x the storage, it’s just an extra $150. 

One scroll later, you must “Choose how you’ll stay connected”:
Wi-Fi only, or Wi-Fi + Cellular.

Again, another $150.

Each upsell is introduced one-by-one, taking up the entire viewport, rather than all at once to gauge them holistically.

As you assess each incremental upsell, 
🔄 "𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 𝗕𝗶𝗮𝘀" 🔄 stops you from reverting decisions you previously committed to.

This controversial email from Mark Zuckerberg to Facebook execs just got leaked.  
 
Here's everything you need to know: 
 
Facebook established a secret internal operation with the aim of understanding how its users were interacting with its competitors. 
 
Named "Project Ghostbusters", with reference to Snapchat’s ghost-like logo, Facebook wanted to figure out a way to analyse encrypted app traffic from users of Snapchat.  
 
Facebook installed so-called 'kits' (using Onavo, a VPN-like service that Facebook acquired in 2013) on its users iOS and Android devices, which allowed Facebook to read network traffic before it got encrypted and sent to Snapchat's servers. 
 
Facebook expanded the tactic, commonly called a "man-in-the-middle attack", to Amazon and YouTube.  
 
Not all execs agreed that "Project Ghostbusters" was a good idea. 
 
In another leaked email exchange, Pedro Canahuati, then-head of security engineering said: "I can’t think of a good argument for why this is okay. No security person is ever comfortable with this, no matter what consent we get from the general public. The general public just doesn’t know how this stuff works.”

Grace Hopper is known as "The Mother of Computer Science".

Sharp-tongued, irreverent, and brilliant, she invented many technologies that are foundational to the modern world. 

Here are her 5 most impactful inventions (and how they shaped the computers we use today): 


1. UNIVAC - the first "all-electronic" computer.

UNIVAC I was the first commercial demonstration of the superiority of electronic computers over electromechanical systems. 

It ran mathematical computations and business applications previously thought impossible for computers.


2. The compiler

A program that translates computer code written in one programming language into another language.

This enabled programmers to write code in more human-readable form, making it simpler and more accessible to a wider audience.


3. FLOW-MATIC

The first programming language that used entirely English words.

Developed for the UNIVAC I, leveraging the compiler, FLOW-MATIC allowed programmers to write instructions and process data using natural language for the first time.


4. COBOL

One of the first popular "high-level" programming languages. 

COBOL enabled large-scale batch and transaction processing jobs, which revolutionised business, finance, and administrative systems.

Even today, COBOL is regularly maintained in critical systems worldwide.


5. Machine-Independent Programming Languages

Hopper advocated for the development of portable software that could run across different systems without modification. 

This principle is a staple in software engineering today, seen in nearly every modern programming language.


Fun fact: In 1947, Hopper found a moth stuck in a computer.

She taped it to a log sheet with the note "First actual case of bug being found." 

This incident popularised the term "debugging".

The moth is preserved in the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History.

This is Arianna Huffington.

She’s written 15 books, founded and sold The Huffington Post for $315 million, and is building a health-tech platform valued over $700 million.

Here are 12 of her most powerful lessons on fear, success, and mindset:

𝗢𝗻 𝗳𝗲𝗮𝗿:

1. Failure is not the opposite of success; it’s part of success.

2. Fearlessness is not the absence of fear. It’s the mastery of fear. It’s about getting up one more time than we fall down.

3. The fastest way to break the cycle of perfectionism and become fearless is to give up the idea of doing it perfectly – indeed to embrace uncertainty and imperfection.

𝗢𝗻 𝘀𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀:

4. Success is commonly defined as money and power, but increasingly that’s not enough. It’s almost like a two-legged stool where you fall over if that’s all you measure your life by.

5. We need to accept that we won’t always make the right decisions, that we’ll screw up royally sometimes – understanding that failure is not the opposite of success, it’s part of success.

6. We don’t need more to be successful. We need less – less clutter, less noise, less distraction.

7. Thrive means not just surviving, but flourishing as a human being – emotionally, physically, spiritually, and professionally.

𝗢𝗻 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱𝘀𝗲𝘁:

8. The only way to create a singularly unique product or point of view is to do the inner work to unearth it.

9. In today’s world, with so much noise, information and stress competing for our attention, mindfulness isn’t a luxury, it’s a necessity

10. Disconnecting from our technology to reconnect with ourselves is absolutely essential for wisdom

11. If you have the ability to inspire others, it’s your duty to do so. Inspiration isn’t something that happens by accident or luck – it’s a responsibility that we all have towards each other.

12. It’s not about having time; it’s about making time. Time is precious and finite, and we can’t afford to waste a single moment pursuing anything but our highest priorities

How to quickly validate any business idea.

The ‘Elevator Pitch’ method:

The ‘Elevator Pitch’ originated in 1853 when elevator pioneer Elisha Otis gave the world’s first demonstration of an elevator with a safety brake.

At the time, elevators were hazardous, and only as stable as their weakest rope.

Otis had a vision for a newer, safer system.

He invented a locking system that would catch and secure a plunging elevator.

Rather than sell his invention through its engineering superiority, he set up a demonstration in front of a crowd.

He hoisted himself three stories up an elevator shaft, and cut his supporting rope with an axe.

He fell immediately, but his stopping mechanism brought him to a safe halt before hitting the ground.

In less than 30 seconds, Otis proved the value of what he was selling.

The ‘Elevator Pitch’ is a short demonstration of a company’s value proposition.

Often a brief, persuasive speech that can be delivered in the time it takes to ride an elevator—typically 30 seconds to 2 minutes.

The idea is: if you can clearly and succinctly explain what your business does, why it’s unique, and what you seek to achieve, all in a couple of minutes, your business has a strong value proposition.

Today, Otis elevators, escalators, and moving walkways move 2.3 billion people per day.

--

P.S. You don’t need to hoist yourself in an elevator shaft to give your “elevator pitch”.

ChatGPT reached 100 million users just two months after launch.

In 2014, he ran a course at Stanford University titled “How to Start a Startup”.

And in just 45 minutes he put together a masterclass on how to build a great product.

Here are 15 of Altman’s product-building principles worth your time: 

1. “Step 1 is to build something that users love.”

2. “One way you that know when this is working, is that you’ll get growth by word of mouth”

3. “Until you’ve built a great product, almost nothing else matters.”

4. “A great product is the secret to long term growth hacking. You should get that right before you worry about anything else.”

5. “Very few startups die from competition, most die because they themselves fail to make something users love.”

6. “Even if you’re building the product for yourself, listen to outside users — they’ll tell you how to make a product they’ll pay for.”

7. “It’s much much easier to make a great product if you have something simple.”

8. “...And its hard to build a great product, and so you want to start with as little surface area as possible.”

9. “Great founders don’t put anyone between themselves and their users.”

10. “Another reason why simple is good, is because it forces you to do one thing extremely well.”

11. “These founders feel physical pain when their product sucks and they want to wake up and fix it.”

12. “You need some users to help with the feedback cycle, but the way to get those users is manually — you should go recruit them by hand.”

13. “One of the great advantages of software startups, is just how short you can make that feedback loop.”

14. “The founders of these companies do things like sales and customer support themselves in the early days.”

15. “Startups live on growth, it’s the indicator of a great product.”

Set priorities like a world-class CEO:

Feeling swamped? You don't need more time.

You need better priorities.

My friend’s Eric Partaker cheat sheet helps you cut through the clutter.

1. Begin with your main goals.
Understand what you hope to achieve.
Because this will be the guide for your decisions.

2. Select your tools.
Choose from the 9 Eric outlined.
Each will bring their own advantage.

3. Prioritise and then execute.
Apply the tools to formulate your plan.
Then simply take action.

This sheet is for everyone. 
Leaders, teams and individuals.

➡️ The Eisenhower Matrix 
Focus on what matters. Important Vs Urgent.

➡️ Burkeman's 3-3-3 Model
Prioritise 3 things. Make it simple.

➡️ Time Blocking
Schedule time for all of your tasks and stick to it.

➡️ The ABCDE Method
This ranks tasks by importance. Take on the A's first.

➡️ The MoSCoW Method
Have full clarity on what matters.

➡️ The Kanban Board
Check your team's progress. Manage tasks in a visual way.

➡️ Warren Buffett’s 25/5 Rule
Put all focus on your top 5. Get rid of the rest.

➡️ The Pareto Principle
Work on the 20% of effort that gives you 80% of results.

➡️ Theory of Constraints
Find the bottlenecks. Fix them right away.

Remember: it's all about how to make choices. 
Everything cannot be a priority.

Utilise these tools.
Learn how to decide wisely.

Focus in and act right away. 
This is how the world’s best do it.

Stop setting impossible goals.

Steal this cheat sheet to achieve meaningful results.

Realistic goal-setting needs purpose, structure, and measurability.

OKRs communicate what you want to accomplish, and what quantifiable milestones will get you there. 

Here’s how they work:

𝗢𝗯𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀
↳ Clear, inspiring goals that motivate and challenge.
↳ Short, memorable, and engaging descriptions.

𝗞𝗲𝘆 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗹𝘁𝘀
↳ Metrics that track progress toward objectives.
↳ Typically two to five per objective.

𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗚𝗼𝗮𝗹𝘀
↳ Long-term, overarching direction.

𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗢𝗯𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝘀
↳ Clear, concise, and memorable.
↳ Think "begin with the end in mind".

𝗗𝗲𝗽𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁-𝗟𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗹 𝗞𝗥𝘀
↳ Owned by a champion.
↳ Directly measure objectives.
↳ Scored regularly and openly.
↳ Annual metric with quarterly targets or milestones.

𝗧𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝗼𝗿 𝗜𝗻𝗱𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗱𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗞𝗥𝘀
↳ Drive department-level KRs.
↳ Achievable by a team or individual.

Set inspiring objectives. 
Break them down into key milestones.

Create clarity. Achieve more.

The root of procrastination isn't laziness, it's anxiety.

And the cost of procrastination is the life you could’ve lived.

My friend Andrew Lokenauth curated 9 helpful strategies for those struggling with procrastination:

𝟭. 𝗣𝗼𝗺𝗼𝗱𝗼𝗿𝗼 𝗧𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗻𝗶𝗾𝘂𝗲:

The Pomodoro Technique involves working in focused 25-minute increments, followed by a 5-minute break. 

After 4 cycles, take a longer break of 15-30 minutes. 

This technique will help you stay focused and avoid burnout

𝟮. "𝟮-𝗠𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘁𝗲 𝗥𝘂𝗹𝗲":

If a task can be done in less than 2 minutes, do it immediately. 

This helps to eliminate small tasks that can quickly add up and make you feel overwhelmed.

𝟯. "𝟱-𝗦𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗱 𝗥𝘂𝗹𝗲":

When you feel the urge to procrastinate, count down from 5 and take immediate action. 

Count backward 5-4-3-2-1:

This helps to overcome the initial resistance to starting a task.

𝟰. 𝟭-𝟯-𝟱 𝗿𝘂𝗹𝗲:

At the start of each day, identify 1 big thing to accomplish, 3 medium things, and 5 small tasks. 

Knock out those priorities first.

𝟱. 𝟴𝟬-𝟮𝟬 𝗿𝘂𝗹𝗲:

Focus on the 20% of tasks that will produce 80% of the results. 

This helps to prioritize tasks and avoid procrastination.

𝟲. "𝗘𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗴":

Do your biggest, nastiest task first thing in the morning, while your willpower is highest. 

It's energizing to get the hard stuff out of the way early.

𝟳. "𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗧𝗼-𝗗𝗼" 𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁:

Identify tasks or activities that are not essential or that can be delegated, and stop doing them.

This helps to free up time and energy for more important tasks.

𝟴. 𝗕𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗸 𝗧𝗮𝘀𝗸𝘀 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗼 𝗦𝗺𝗮𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗿 𝗣𝗶𝗲𝗰𝗲𝘀:

One of the main reasons we procrastinate is because a task seems too big and overwhelming. 

To make it more manageable, try breaking it down into smaller, more doable parts. 

For example, if you have a big project, break it down into steps like researching, outlining, writing, and editing. 

You'll feel less overwhelmed and more motivated to get started.

𝟵. 𝗘𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗺𝘂𝗹𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗮𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴:

Trying to juggle multiple tasks guarantees that your mind will wander. 

Singletask with ruthless focus instead.

👍 2024 will be the year you overcome procrastination!
♻️ Too many people struggle with procrastination! Help them by sharing this!

North Star Metrics 101

My Mum texted me asking, “what exactly is a North Star Metric?”

Here’s what I sent her:

So you’ve built a product, and people are using it.

You start tracking everything you can to measure how well the product is performing:

- Daily/Weekly/Monthly Active Users
- Customer Acquisition Cost
- Customer growth rate
- Net expansion rate
- Conversion rate
- Feature usage
- Lifetime value
- Contraction
- Retention
- Drop-off

Invariably, you run into the same problem:

You want all key metrics to go up, but you’re not sure which ones to prioritise investing in.

The answer?

The North Star Metric: A single metric that defines success for your business.

“Wouldn’t that just be revenue?”

Although it’s tempting to always default to financial KPIs, the best North Star Metrics help businesses understand how customers truly derive value from their product.

Put simply - the more you drive your North Star, the more 𝙫𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙚 your business creates.

If you want to do creative projects but never have the energy, try this: 
 
Nature is more than just a backdrop for relaxation; it actively enhances our creative thinking and problem-solving abilities. 
 
Getting out into nature with a clear aim to do creative work as a massively underrated tool. 
 
Here’s my protocol for an intentional day of personal projects: 
 
→ 𝗠𝗼𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗥𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗲 
Begin your morning by stepping outside. Feel the natural elements (the sun, a breeze, the texture of grass). Just a couple of minutes can really clear the mind, calibrate your senses, and sharpen focus. 
 
→ 𝗦𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 
Carry a notebook and pen on a short walk in a nearby park or natural setting, away from digital distractions. Write down a maximum of 3 things you’d like to focus on. Put a star next to the one that is your highest priority - the one that, once completed, would make the day a success. 
 
→ 𝗝𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗮𝗹 
To get the creative juices flowing, handwrite down a short answer to each of these prompts: 
• Describe your natural surroundings. 
• What’s 1 trait you want to exhibit today? 
• What’s 1 thing you’re grateful for? 
 
→ 𝗗𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 
Curate a workspace with natural elements (e.g., plants, natural light, open windows for fresh air). The more minimal and distraction-free, the better. Brew your hot beverage of choice, take a deep breath, and start your day with a 2-hour uninterrupted block focussed on your highest priority task. 
 
→ 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗸𝘀 
Introduce short, regular walking breaks in your routine, preferably in natural, green spaces. Experiment with different levels of stimulus: Notebook, no notebook. Music, no music. Use this time for reflection or pondering creative challenges, letting the natural environment stimulate new perspectives. 
 
→ 𝗪𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼𝘄𝗻 
As daylight shifts to dusk, allow your mind to naturally transition to relaxation. Under soft lighting, jot down any lingering thoughts or reflections in a journal. Close the cognitive chapter on productivity, and enjoy an evening of leisurely reading, cooking, and resting. 
 
--  
 
This is an excerpt from an initiative I recently took part in called 'The nature of work' - a collaboration between Unyoked and LinkedIn.  
 
They invited Lizzie Hedding, Samantha Wong, James Hurman, Cayla Dengate, Jimmy Lyell and I to create a guide on using nature to slow down and focus on the things that really matter.  
 
🏕️ One takeaway for me: Whether you're an athlete, VC, or musician... try to build more exposure to the natural world into your daily, weekly, monthly and yearly rhythms. 
 
Hope you enjoy the guide as much as we did making it.

Steve Jobs had a simple rule for designing the perfect user interface: 
 
The 3-click rule. 
 
Steve was intimately involved in the design and development of the original iPod. 
 
Those that knew him said he had the same response to nearly every problem - 
 
“Simplify!” 
 
During product demos, he would go over every screen and apply a rigid test: 
 
If a user wants to use a core feature (eg play a song) ... 
 
they must be able to get there in three clicks. 
 
The success of the iPod changed the industry forever, and the 3-click rule quickly spread across product development circles. 
 
Airbnb founder Brian Chesky was always adamant users are never more than 3 clicks away from a booking. 
 
Same as reading trending content from your favourite subreddit. 
 
Or watching your favourite Youtuber’s latest video. 
 
If you're building a consumer product, ask yourself: 
 
How many clicks does it take for a user to reach your unique-selling-point?

DoorDash pulled off one of the most underappreciated market share robberies of all time.

In just 3 years, they exploded from 16% to 53% share of the US delivery app market.

Here’s 4 strategies they used to crush Uber Eats, GrubHub and Postmates:

1. Avoiding the competition

DoorDash targeted restaurants without delivery services, often with pre-existing customer bases, rather than competing for newer restaurants with multiple other providers. 

2. Empowering restaurants

DoorDash acquired restaurants by providing them with not just delivery services, but insights they never had before: popular dishes in the area, customer demographics, local delivery times, and more.

3. Maximising AOV

DoorDash focussed on winning outer suburbs with large family homes - an underserved segment with a much higher average-order-value (AOV) than urban regions.

4. Brand positioning

When Covid hit, DoorDash supported its Dashers and restaurants by offering payment advances and other benefits, creating significant supply growth for their marketplace.

Doordash saw the opportunity, developed a plan... and they delivered.

Nintendo was founded in 1889, originally making Hanafuda playing cards.

But, it took 90 years of experimenting as a:

→ ‘love hotel’ chain 
→ toy company 
... before they released their first video game. 
 
What was it about their video gaming strategy that defined their success today? 
 
Legendary president and CEO of Nintendo Satoru Iwatu once said, “𝘈𝘣𝘰𝘷𝘦 𝘢𝘭𝘭, 𝘷𝘪𝘥𝘦𝘰 𝘨𝘢𝘮𝘦𝘴 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘮𝘦𝘢𝘯𝘵 𝘵𝘰 𝘣𝘦 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘰𝘯𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨: 𝘧𝘶𝘯. 𝘍𝘶𝘯 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘦𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘺𝘰𝘯𝘦.” 
 
In the 1980s video game boom, competitor game developers duked it out over tech spec superiority, fighting over their share of the ‘core gamer segment’. 
 
Nintendo were the first gaming manufacturer to realise: 
 
𝗧𝗵𝗲𝘆 𝗱𝗶𝗱𝗻’𝘁 𝘀𝗲𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵.

Try not to hear this.

Impossible. Why?

A marketing concept known as 'Sensory Hijacking'. 

When we observe familiar information, our brains fill in the blanks with expected sensations.

A very strong and involuntary connection between the stimulus and the sense that it triggers is known as "associative synesthesia".

'Sensory Hijacking' or 'Sensory Marketing' exploits this by using visuals to evoke sounds, smells, or tastes associated with the product. 

Brands can leverage these cues to spark cravings, trigger emotion, and create multi-sensory experiences that make us 'feel' (not just 'see').

Give me 2 minutes, and I’ll teach you 6 lessons for writing good strategies.

𝟭. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗞𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗲𝗹 𝗼𝗳 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆
Strategy is designing a way to deal with a challenge. A good strategy contains a diagnosis (defining the challenge), a guiding policy (overall approach), and coherent actions (how the policy will be carried out).

𝟮. 𝗚𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆 𝘃𝘀. 𝗕𝗮𝗱 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆
A good strategy is simple, identifies key challenges, includes actionable steps, and is designed to be coherent. Bad strategy is vague, lacks actions, and fails to coordinate efforts, often mistaking goals for strategy.

𝟯. 𝗜𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗳𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗕𝗮𝗱 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆
Four major hallmarks of bad strategy include fluff (using vague language), failure to face the challenge, mistaking goals for strategy, and having bad strategic objectives. Recognize bad strategies by avoiding these pitfalls.

𝟰. 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝘄𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿
Beware of "Dog’s Dinner Objectives" (unconnected objectives), and avoid conflating OKRs (*exercise in goal setting and measuring*) with strategy. Blue Sky Objectives and restating desired states also lead to bad strategy.

𝟱. 𝗦𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗣𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿 𝗶𝗻 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆
Leverage finding an imbalance in a situation, and exploiting it to produce a disproportionately large payoff; choose an objective that is close enough at hand to be feasible; build chain-link systems for excellence, design coherent strategies, maintain focus, and understand growth as a result, not a strategy.

𝟲. 𝗗𝘆𝗻𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗰𝘀, 𝗜𝗻𝗲𝗿𝘁𝗶𝗮, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗘𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗼𝗽𝘆
Anticipate industry dynamics, exploit inertia by understanding competitors' slow adaptation, and watch for entropy in your organisation. Recognising these sources of power helps in creating effective strategies.

This is a concise summary of the ideas in “Good Strategy, Bad Strategy” by Richard Rumelt a canonical book for anyone interested in the topic.

Payal Kadakia sold her 8-year old company for over $1 billion.

From the daughter of Indian immigrants to startup icon, here is Payal's incredible story.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗘𝗮𝗿𝗹𝘆 𝗬𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀:

Her parents, who had moved from India to New Jersey, placed a huge emphasis on providing Payal with a complete education. 

She grew up in the #1 rated school district, and her early life revolved around dance, fitness, and a love for math and science.

In 2011, with a degree from MIT, Payal started her career at Bain Consulting and Warner Music. 

She quickly grew tired of corporate life and gave herself 14 days to come up with an idea for her own company.

Inspired by her friends building online platforms in the mobile app goldrush, she envisioned a solution to a personal pain point - difficulty booking dance classes. 

The idea for ClassPass was born.

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗽𝘁:

ClassPass iterated through a number of business model concepts:

→ A search engine for fitness classes.

The discovery process wasn’t a sticky enough problem for users - rather they had issues committing to to a healthy lifestyle change. 

→ A Groupon-style package of 10 classes for $49.

Started generating revenue, but wasn't sustainable because users weren’t going back to purchase a studio membership. Studios were giving away 10 classes for free, but users weren't converting afterwards.

→ A 10-class subscription for $99 per month.

The ongoing commitment kept users accountable, and the variety of classes had them hooked on the app. 

Product-market-fit.

Fast forward 4 years, and ClassPass had booked over 17 million fitness classes. 

A year later, 35 million reservations, and an aggressive expansion across the US. 

Years of trial and error was only possible for someone truly obsessed with the problem space from a young age:
• She would miss night outs to go dancing
• She left her last performance review early to go to dancing practice
• She started a dance studio, "The Sa Dance Company" (where she still performs to this day!)

𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗰𝗾𝘂𝗶𝘀𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻:

In 2021 ClassPass was acquired by Mindbody, the leading booking engine for fitness classes. 

Mindbody helps users book local fitness options, but didn't offer the multi-vendor bundles that ClassPass thrived on. 

No pricing terms of the all-stock deal were disclosed, but it was reported that:
• Mindbody would hold between a 60%-70% of the combined entity.
• ClassPass was valued "significantly" above $1 billion.

Today, Payal is a successful author, an impactful advocate for female entrepreneurship, and the artistic director of 'The Sa Dance Company'.

How to make 2024 the year you finally build an audience (as a full-time employee). 
 
I grew my audience to 100k on LinkedIn and email on the side of my full-time job.  
 
Here is the 7-step playbook I’d follow if I were starting again from scratch: 
 
𝗡𝗼𝘁𝗲: This is specifically for professionals wanting to build a high-value network and create business opportunities. Growing generalist audiences in niches like food, sport, or fashion require a different playbook! 
 
Here we go: 
 
𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟭: Just get started 
 
Remember, you have a better chance of seeing this through if you publish a post today, than if you spend the next 3 weeks ‘defining your niche’ and ‘learning the algorithm’. Momentum matters.  
 
𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟮: Leverage your existing network 
 
One of the best (or worst, depending on who you ask) things about LinkedIn is you don’t start from 0. You start with your existing connections. Make use of it! Tell your friends, and encourage them to engage. Ask your colleagues if anyone wants to join you, turning it into a collaborative challenge.  
 
𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟯: Consistency is key 
 
Most people fail because they give up (not because of their content). Start with a realistic posting schedule—one post per week. Block out time in your calendar. Stick to it religiously. Set alarms. It’s just 1 post - make it happen.  
 
𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟰: Craft content you'd enjoy reading 
 
The only content you’ll stick to writing over the long term is content that interests you. Don't try to write about topics that don’t give you energy. Don’t follow trends. Write for yourself.  
 
𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟱: Write fast. Break. Edit slow. 
 
Focus on rapid content creation without getting bogged down by perfectionism. Later, during a separate session, ideally the next day, refine your work. This prevents writers block, and helps you fix elements that may were overlooked in the initial writing session. 
 
𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟲: Leverage Micro-Moments 
 
An underrated attribute of audience growth as a side-hustle for full-timers is that you can make small amounts of progress, 5mins at a time. Make use of lunch breaks, coffee walks or moments of downtime during your day. Respond to comments, share quick updates, engage with your network. Every action counts.  
 
𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟳: Systems 
 
The more you write, the more you realise how much work ‘around the writing’ there is. Create systems that automate routine tasks, build leverage, and free up your time. Save ideas to a database. Use a prioritisation framework. Calendar your ‘writing hours’. Don’t just write content - build a content machine.

How Airbnb generated users on autopilot back in 2008.

Airbnb knew that Craigslist had a massive user base actively seeking rentals.

In order to generate more impressions (and improve completion rate) on Airbnb listings, they constructed a seamless flow for hosts to cross-post their listings to Craigslist.

When users posted on Airbnb, they were given the option to “post to Craigslist”, which generated a pre-filled listing template.

Under the hood, the bot: 
→ visited Craigslist 
→ filled in some forms 
→ opened a draft listing 
→ created an HTML template 
→ copied the unique URL string
→ returned it to the user for publishing

To make the flow as frictionless as possible, the bot automatically added a compelling title, detailed description, category, location, high-quality images, and crucially - a direct link back to the listing on Airbnb’s website.

By equipping hosts with tools to broadcast their rentals, Airbnb tapped into Craigslist’s vast traffic base, funnelling new users back to their own site.

12 of the wisest things ever said by Melanie Perkins:

1. “Solve customer problems and make sure that the customer is representative of a large market and then you will have a pretty good formula."

2. "Anyone can have a solution but if no one cares about it, unfortunately, you are not going to have a very big company."

3. “The rejection is often not because of the reasons you think they are rejecting you.”

4. "Plant lots and lots of seeds and hopefully one will grow!"

5. “If you are determined and want it, you can just go for it.

6. ”It’s never too late to exercise the power of determination. Figure out something you’d like to succeed at, and then do it.”

7. “I think innovation is solving a problem. That can be a small problem that just affects you, that can be a large problem that affects society. Innovation is getting to the crux of a problem and solving it.”

8. “Provide real value: the power of this cannot be underestimated in both your product and marketing.”

9. “Start niche and go wide. By starting ‘niche’ (with Fusion) and then going wide (with Canva) we were able to really get a deep understanding of our customers’ problem and solve it well.”

10. “SEO: when people are looking for your product it would be crazy not to let them find it.”

11. “Every time we’d get a really tricky question from investors we’d iterate on our deck to put the hardest questions they asked right at the front of the deck.”

12. “I wanted to make design software simple, online and collaborative.”

What’s your favourite quote?

99% of businesses have absolutely no idea how to analyse their competitors. 
 
Here’s an overpowered tactic I actually use: 
 
Let’s say I want an inside scoop on the current strategy of a competitor, new market entrant, interesting brand etc. 
 
Their landing page, about page and product page all tell me ‘𝙝𝙤𝙬 the brand positions itself’. 
 
But an interesting data point you can go after is ‘𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 the brand positions itself’. 
 
Chatspot is a free AI app developed as a side-project by Dharmesh Shah (founder of HubSpot). 
 
If I ask it “What keywords does [company] buy?”, it tells me: 
 
· Which keywords the company is buying 
· Where they rank for those keywords 
· What the keyword search volume is 
· What the cost-per-click is 
 
The keywords, rankings, volume, and CPCs, tell me: 
 
· Which competitors they are targeting 
· Which traffic they are stealing 
· Which trends they are riding 
· Which niches they value 
 
X-Ray vision for anyone working in areas like strategy, product, or marketing.

Snapchat is one of the most fascinating tech acquirers of all time.

When you break it down, their entire business is an amalgamation of acquired startups.

Here are the 25 deals that shaped the Snapchat of today:

1. AddLive (2014) - $30m
Became Snapchats ‘Video Chat’ feature.

2. Vergence Labs (2014) - $15m
Became ‘Spectacles’, Snapchat’s smart glasses hardware line.

3. Scan me (2014) - $50m
Became ‘Snapcodes’, Snapchat’s personalised QR code feature.

4. Looksery (2015) - $150m
Became ‘Filters’ and ‘Lenses’, Snapchat’s facial recognition and modification technology.

5. Bitstrips (2016) - $100m
Became ‘Bitmojis’, Snapchat’s personalised avatars.

6. Seene (2016) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s ‘3D Selfies’, powering face swaps and other AR overlays.

7. Vurb (2016) - $114.5m
Became Snapchat’s local business search and discovery features.

8. Flite (2016) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s tech powering 360° video ads and vertical video ads.

9. Cimagine (2016) - $30-40m
Became Snapchat’s AR product visualisation features.

10. Ctrl Me Robotics (2017) - <$1m
Became part of Snapchat’s hardware team.

11. Placed (2017) - $135m
Became Snapchat’s ad tracking for foot traffic and conversions in physical stores.

12. Zenly (2017) - $213m
Became ‘Snap Map’, Snapchat’s interactive social maps.

13. Strong Codes (2017) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s code protection technology.

14. Metamarkets (2017) - $100m
Became Snapchat’s analytics dashboard for advertisers.

15. PlayCanvas (2018) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s ‘Lens Studio’, where developers build AR Lens effects.

16. Teleport (2018) - $8m
Became part of Snapchat’s ‘Filters’ technology, powering features like hair colour changes.

17. AIFactory (2020) - $166m
Became ‘Cameos’, Snapchat’s animated selfie video feature.

18. Voca ai (2020) - $70m
Became Snapchat’s Ai-based voice agents for customer support.

19. Voisey (2020) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s music creation and sharing features.

20. Ariel AI (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s AR experiences team.

21. Fit Analytics (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s virtual clothing try-on and sizing features.

22. Screenshop (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s product recommendations based on images saved to ‘Memories’.

23. Demand Sage (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s ad reporting and analytics features.

24. Pixel8earth (2021) - $7.6m
Became part of ‘Local Lenses’, Snapchat’s location-based AR experiences.

25. WaveOptics (2021) - $500m
Became Snapchat’s AR display manufacturing team.

Why did Netflix pay a group of hackers $1 million in 2009?

Netflix’s entire business rides on its personalisation algorithm.

80% of content their users watch is recommended to them by Netflix.

Their recommendation engine is so efficient at preventing user abandonment, Netflix believes it saves them more than $1 billion per year.

But how did they develop such a powerful algorithm?

In the early days, they came up with a novel strategy involving nothing more than a good ol’ fashioned $1 million prize pool...

In 2006, Netflix announced they would pay $1 million to anyone in the world who could improve their recommendation algorithm by 10%.

Netflix open-sourced a dataset of user ratings and asked participants to predict how those users would rate movies they hadn't seen yet.

Thousands of teams tackled the problem, sharing their results and algorithms along the way.

After 3 years, a group of Austrian, Canadian, American, and Israeli hackers called “Bellkor's Pragmatic Chaos” developed a solution verified to be a 10.05% improvement, and took home the grand prize.

The genius of this strategy is the way it plays into human psychology: by aligning competitive incentives, the ‘Netflix Prize’ was a faster, cheaper, and less risky alternative to in-house research and development.

For the hackers working on the problem, $1m created the allure of a windfall gain.

Netflix made it no secret that to them the $1m was a colossal bargain for a landmark product enhancement.

A public leaderboard added fuel to the fire by creating visibility between the progress of contestants.

If no solution was found, Netflix didn’t spend a penny (on the cash prize or in time-invested).

The ‘Netflix Prize’ still stands as one of history's best best win-win-win scenarios:

Hackers won a million bucks. 

Users won better recommendations. 

Netflix won an even bigger moat for their best-in-class product.

𝗔𝘁 𝟯𝟱 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀 𝗼𝗹𝗱, 𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝟭𝟱 𝗽𝗶𝗲𝗰𝗲𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝗵𝗲’𝗱 𝗴𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗽𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝘀𝗲𝗹𝗳: 
(From his personal blog, in a post titled “Advice”)

1. Go deep on things. Become an expert.

2. In particular, try to go deep on 𝘮𝘶𝘭𝘵𝘪𝘱𝘭𝘦 things. One of the main things you should try to achieve by age 20 is some sense for which kinds of things you 𝘦𝘯𝘫𝘰𝘺 doing. 

3. Don't stress out too much about how valuable the things you're going deep on are... but don't ignore it either. It should be a factor you weigh but not by itself dispositive.

4. To the extent that you enjoy working hard, do. Subject to that constraint, it's not clear that the returns to effort ever diminish substantially.

5. Make friends over the internet with people who are great at things you're interested in. The internet is one of the biggest advantages you have over prior generations. Leverage it.

6. Aim to read a lot.

7. If you think something is important but people older than you don't hold it in high regard, there's a reasonable chance that you're right and they're wrong. Status lags by a generation or more.

8. Above all else, don't make the mistake of judging your success based on your current peer group. By all means make friends but being weird as a teenager is generally good.

9. 𝘉𝘶𝘵 having good social skills confers life-long benefits. So, don't write them off. Get good at making a good first impression, being funny, speaking publicly.

10. Make things. Operating in a space with a lot of uncertainty is a very different experience to learning something.

11. More broadly, nobody is going to teach you to think for yourself. A large fraction of what people around you believe is mistaken. Internalize this and practice coming up with your own worldview.

12. If you're in the US and go to a good school, there are a lot of forces that will push you towards following train-tracks laid by others rather than charting a course yourself. 

13. Figure out a way to travel to San Francisco and to meet other people who've moved there to pursue their dreams.

14. Find vivid examples of success in the domains you care about. If you want to become a great scientist, try to find ways to spend time with good (or, ideally, great) scientists in person.

15. People who did great things often did so at very surprisingly young ages. So, hurry up! You can do great things.

Tracy Young sold her 7-year old startup for $875m.

From humble beginnings as the daughter of Vietnamese refugees to a Silicon Valley icon.

Here’s her incredible story:

Young’s parent’s fled Vietnam on a fishing boat with hundreds of others.

After a stay in Malaysia, her family was sponsored by a Lutheran priest to live in a church in California.

Even without speaking the language, Young’s parents started a wholesale food supply business.

Fast forward to 2011, they had put all 3 children through college, and Young was working as a construction engineer.

Frustrated by an industry that operated on paper, she identified a business opportunity involving Apple’s latest product:

The iPad.

Paper-based building plans were brought onto building sites, reprinted constantly, and worked on by many collaborators.

This was expensive, inefficient, and a headache for construction teams.

Young started PlanGrid - a suite of mobile-friendly tools for digital construction blueprints.

Here’s 2 awesome stories showing the founding team’s grit, urgency, and willpower:

𝟭. 𝗦𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗻𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁

In order to get their product in the hands of customers, Young had to buy as many iPads as possible.

At the time, Apple limited the number of tablets you could buy.

Young and her team wore disguises and maxed out their credit cards to procure enough devices to load up with their software for early customers.

𝟮. 𝗙𝗼𝗿𝗰𝗲-𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗱𝘂𝗰𝘁 𝗮𝗱𝗼𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

Young’s team knew construction conferences were a dense market to attack, but renting a booth cost $5,000+.

Instead, they bought $60 tickets and went up to strangers saying, “Hey, wanna see something cool?”

Regardless of their answer, they’d run the demo.

To this day, 2 of PlanGrid’s top 10 customers are from those early conferences.

Over the next 7 years, Young scaled PlanGrid so flawlessly that their story is now considered 𝘵𝘩𝘦 Silicon Valley playbook to crack big, established industries:

• Call every single lead.
• Prioritise predictable growth.
• All staff can demo the product.
• Get the product in customers hands.
• Attack core B2B personas and expand.

In 2018, PlanGrid was acquired by AutoDesk for a whopping $875m.

Today, Young runs TigerEye, software that tracks and predicts future performance of sales teams.

She also runs a newsletter coined “Predictable Growth” where she interviews female leaders driving revenue for their businesses.

23 things I learnt in 2023

Is Jan 23rd a bit late for a post like this?

Perhaps.

1. Shipping late is 1000x better than not shipping at all. 

2. Similarly, a ‘little’ progress is 1000x better (not just a ‘little’ better) than no progress.

3. Small business accounting is more complicated than I thought.

4. Procrastination is generally less ‘mindlessly distracted’ and more ‘knowingly destructive’.

5. Procrastination is more to do with starting something than doing it to completion.

6. Once you start a meditation, you won’t ever stop halfway.

7. Meditation does actually work - significantly more aware of my mindset ‘in the moment’.

8. I'll never regret going for a swim.

9. I needed automations that reduce friction to basically 0 to start journalling regularly.

10. I have to physically list names of people / companies to respond to, and cross them out once actioned, otherwise I’ll forget. 

11. Working out consistently is more about momentum than motivation. The #1 indicator for "will I work out today?" is not "how motivated am I?", it's "how many times have I worked out this week?"

12. “Resistance is experienced as fear; the degree of fear equates to the strength of Resistance.”

13. With enough conviction and focus, I can create cool things I’m proud of.

14. Consuming puts you to work for the internet, creating puts the internet to work for you.

15. There are good breaks (walking without a phone, making tea) and bad breaks (doomscrolling, checking inboxes). A heuristic for bad breaks = introducing random new information/tasks.

16. Checking my phone before getting out of bed is the worst possible start to a day.

17. After a certain point, ignoring DMs / emails / connections becomes a practical necessity. Despite this, it still ‘feels’ rude to do. 

18. Using my calendar as the ‘source of truth to-do list’ works. I will never go back to not doing this. 

19. You will never ‘find the time’ - you have to ‘make the time’.

20. I’d always rather an ‘oh well’ than a ‘what if’.

21. The more messages / emails you send, the more you receive. This can be both good and bad, depending on objectives.

22. Sustainable / repeatable progress always comes down to systems.

23. “Most knowledge worth having comes from practice. It comes from doing. It comes from creating... So stop reading and start creating. Paint, draw, compose, code, or plan. It will be hard. It will be slow. It will be frustrating. But I promise it will be worth it.”

Emphasis on the 𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘴 - implementation is work in progress! 

But still, we try.


💬 Agree? Disagree? I'd love to hear your thoughts on these ideas in the comments.

Photos on the Unsplash home page reach more people than the cover of TIME Magazine, a post on Kim Kardashian’s Instagram, or the front page of the New York Times.  
 
But, the image-sharing platform now generating 𝟱,𝟭𝟲𝟮 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗽𝗲𝗿 𝘀𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗱 (!) originally started as a marketing experiment ⤵ 
 
Unsplash was originally a simple Tumblr account, with the sole purpose of driving traffic towards Crew, a freelancer marketplace.  
 
The Crew team had hired a photographer to shoot stock photos, and decided to share the best leftover images online.  
 
Unsplash, the Tumblr page, promised 10 high-res curated photos every 10 days - 100% free to download for personal or professional use.  
 
By providing goodwill into the ecosystem, and featuring a prominent backlink to Crew, they hoped to drive designers and developers looking for free photography assets to their marketplace. 
 
Unsplash immediately rose to #1 on Hacker News, getting 50,000 visitors in the first hour. 
 
The first signal of Unsplash’s parabolic growth. 
 
And, a prototype of the principle that underpinned their distribution blueprint: 
 
💡 𝗗𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗱𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘀. 
 
It doesn’t matter if you’re building a SaaS company, media brand, ecommerce store, or marketplace, there’s something you can learn from the Unsplash story. 
 
Today's newsletter breaks down 3 tactics they used to build virality into their product.
