This guy pulled off one of the most exponential app launches of all time.

In just 10 days, he was adding 30,000 new users PER HOUR.

That’s more than 8 per second.

𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗲𝘅𝗮𝗰𝘁 𝟲-𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝗴𝘂𝗲𝗿𝗿𝗶𝗹𝗹𝗮 𝗺𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘆𝗯𝗼𝗼𝗸 𝗵𝗲 𝘂𝘀𝗲𝗱:

But first - who is he and what exactly was the app?

Nikita Bier famously sold his first company ‘tbh’ to Facebook for $100m.

After his non-compete clause expired, he quit and started his next venture, ‘Gas’.

‘Gas’ is a polling app that lets high-schoolers anonymously compliment their friends.

After launching in August 2022, Nikita and his team:

- Made $10m in revenue
- Sold to Discord for 8-figures in 4 months

So how did he grow it so fast?

𝟭. 𝗛𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝘀𝗼𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗯𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

To create hype and exclusivity, he would target specific high schools 1-by-1.

For each high school, he created a private Instagram account with the school’s name.

For example, '@gas.georgiahigh'.

𝟮. 𝗧𝗮𝗿𝗴𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗯𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝗰𝗾𝘂𝗶𝘀𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

Nikita discovered that teenage Instagram users would often list their school in their bio.

He crawled each school’s page and followed all accounts that referenced the school’s name.

𝟯. 𝗕𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱 𝗮 𝗯𝗼𝗼𝘁𝗹𝗲𝗴 ‘𝘄𝗮𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁’

Most students, curious about the mystery profile, would request to follow back.

But Nikita wouldn’t accept any requests...

yet.

𝟰. 𝗟𝗮𝘂𝗻𝗰𝗵 𝗱𝗮𝘆 𝘀𝗽𝗶𝗸𝗲

At 3:00pm on launch day, when everyone got out of school at the same time, he accepted all the follow requests simultaneously.

Every student got the ‘follow accepted’ notification at once.

The result?

𝟱. 𝗦𝘆𝗻𝗰𝗵𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗳𝘂𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹

Large numbers of students in a concentrated area started showing each other and talking about Gas…

at the same time.

When they opened the Instagram profile, they saw a simple bio:

“See who likes you” with a link to download Gas.

𝟲.

Every student got the ‘follow accepted’ notification at once.

The result?

𝟱. 𝗦𝘆𝗻𝗰𝗵𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗶𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗳𝘂𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗹

Large numbers of students in a concentrated area started showing each other and talking about Gas…

at the same time.

When they opened the Instagram profile, they saw a simple bio:

“See who likes you” with a link to download Gas.

𝟲. 𝗥𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲

Nikita conducted these launches every few weeks, targeting one high school at a time.

Each launch he spotted inefficiencies and further automated the process.

𝟳. 𝗩𝗶𝗿𝗮𝗹 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗱-𝗼𝗳-𝗺𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗵

The launch strategy seeded the concept in schools across the country.

From there, the app grew organically through user referrals. 

The best part?

He spent $0 on paid marketing.

📊 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗮𝘆:  
 
Every major streaming service has raised their prices 10-72%. 
 
In fact, nearly all of them within the past ~6 months. 
 
Apple Music → Oct 2022 
YouTube Music → July 2023 
YouTube Premium → July 2023 
Spotify → July 2023 
Peacock → Aug 2023 
Paramount+ → Aug 2023 
HBO Max → Oct 2023 
Netflix → Oct 2023 
Hulu → Oct 2023 
Disney+ → Oct 2023 
Apple TV+ → Oct 2023 
 
Fascinating oligopoly (small number of major players) dynamics at play: 
 
The first mover takes on the most risk - weighing up the estimated churn vs ROI. 
 
When the first mover commits, that gives permission for others to ‘follow the leader’, with decreased churn risk. 
 
The inverse of a destructive price war, where all players compete by dropping prices, causing a ‘race to the bottom’.

It took me 39 consecutive daily posts to go viral. 
 
Total impressions from first 38 posts: 
➔ 140k 
 
Total impressions from 39th post: 
➔ 4.1 million 
 
The original plan was to stop after 1 month 🤦‍♂️ 
 
Here's 3 takeaways from those early days: 
 
1. Getting "1% better" each post really does work. 
 
➔ I spent way too much time researching growth strategy, how to go viral, best time to post, when to comment etc. all before I even started writing! It turns out, the only way to put out high-quality and platform-optimised content is to start posting and improve a single aspect each day. 
 
2. The best growth hack is simply to not stop. 
 
➔ A regular cadence doesn't just ensure you maximise your exposure in the feed, it also helps you to form a daily writing habit. Generally speaking, people at 20k followers haven't figured something out that people at 5k haven't - they just haven't stopped posting! 
 
3. Being great is just being good repeatedly 
 
➔ If you look at any of the largest creators on the platform - the one thing they all have in common is consistency. Sure they have adopted tactics, leveraged networks, and gone viral along the way, but it's the sheer volume of content that allows them to iterate and compound their way to success. 
 
If you're writing online - 
this is a friendly reminder to keep going.

I quit my dream job in the strategy team at Atlassian to go full-time on my side-hustle. 

Here's why:

The last 6 months has been equal parts gripping and fatiguing.

When I launched Strategy Breakdowns in June, I had no concrete expectations regarding growth or monetisation, but safe to say any guess I could’ve made was exceeded. 

Scaling a side-project to 33,000 readers and a fully sold-out ad calendar from exclusively inbound leads is genuinely astonishing and humbling. 

But, the approach taken was not a sustainable one. 

Working every weekday plus writing / growing / selling every weeknight and weekend was only viable for a finite period of time. It didn’t take long before the inevitable decision-point emerged: 

𝗢𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝟭:
Cut back, take a breather, and accept that the future of Strategy Breakdowns is a ‘passion-project’ that will never become what I believe it could be.

𝗢𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝟮:
Keep building on the side, risk burning out, and wait indefinitely for the 𝘰𝘱𝘱𝘰𝘳𝘵𝘶𝘯𝘦 '𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘥𝘢𝘺’ 𝘮𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵 that going all-in seems reasonable.

𝗢𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝟯:
Build conviction. Model a few financial scenarios. Commit to a rough plan. Tell my boss I’m leaving.

I chose option 3.

Curious?

In a few hours, I’ll be sharing that rough plan with all Strategy Breakdowns subscribers.

Plus, how the idea came to be, the exact processes & tools I used to build it, and learnings from the last 6 months.

If I had to make a playbook for predictable growth, it would start with these metrics. 

From MRR to NPS, this cheat sheet provides a baseline for key SaaS metrics you should be tracking. 

𝗚𝗿𝗼𝘄𝘁𝗵 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀:
• 𝗠𝗥𝗥: Your subscription revenue heartbeat.
• 𝗔𝗥𝗥: Forecasted yearly revenue based on monthly performance
• 𝗖𝗔𝗖: Cost of acquiring new customers.
• 𝗟𝗧𝗩: Average customer's lifetime value.
• 𝗖𝗠𝗚𝗥: Normalised month-over-month growth rate.
• 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗠𝗥𝗥: Additional revenue from existing customers.

𝗥𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀:
• 𝗗𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗮𝗿 𝗥𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: Ongoing revenue generation within a cohort.
• 𝗖𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿 𝗥𝗲𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Track the proportion of retained customers.
• 𝗖𝗵𝘂𝗿𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Subscription cancellations.
• 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Reduction in subscription spend.
• 𝗡𝗣𝗦: Customer likelihood to recommend your business.
• 𝗖𝗦𝗔𝗧: Customer satisfaction levels.

𝗦𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀:
• 𝗔𝗻𝗻𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁 𝗩𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲: Average annualised revenue per contract.
• 𝗔𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗦𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗖𝘆𝗰𝗹𝗲 𝗟𝗲𝗻𝗴𝘁𝗵: Time taken for leads to convert.
• 𝗪𝗶𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Deal success against opportunities.
• 𝗠𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗡𝘂𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿: Efficiency of Net New ARR compared to expenses.
• 𝗤𝘂𝗼𝘁𝗮 𝗔𝘁𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Assess sales teams' performance against targets.
• 𝗔𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗗𝗲𝗮𝗹 𝗦𝗶𝘇𝗲: Average value of each closed deal.

• 𝗪𝗶𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Deal success against opportunities.
• 𝗠𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗰 𝗡𝘂𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿: Efficiency of Net New ARR compared to expenses.
• 𝗤𝘂𝗼𝘁𝗮 𝗔𝘁𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Assess sales teams' performance against targets.
• 𝗔𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗗𝗲𝗮𝗹 𝗦𝗶𝘇𝗲: Average value of each closed deal.

𝗘𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗺𝗲𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗰𝘀:
• 𝗗𝗔𝗨: Track daily active users engaging with your product.
• 𝗠𝗔𝗨: Track monthly active users engaging with your product.
• 𝗗𝗔𝗨/𝗠𝗔𝗨: Ensure a healthy product usage ratio.
• 𝗣𝗮𝗶𝗱 𝗦𝗲𝗮𝘁𝘀 𝗣𝗲𝗿 𝗖𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗿: Average user licences per paid account.
• 𝗙𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗧𝗼 𝗣𝗮𝗶𝗱 𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗥𝗮𝘁𝗲: Measure conversion of free users to paid.
• 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀: Key actions during trial periods for enhanced conversion.

This is just a starting point. You must always add other metrics depending on your business model, objectives, and market.

Just 8 months after launching, Facebook had over 1 million monthly active users.

Here's 2x little-known tactics from their early days that helped them build software at unparalleled speed.

All new hires at the company had 2 onboarding tasks:

Day 1: Get their dev environment set up
Day 2: Commit code to all users

This is magnitudes faster than most startups, which don’t have you ship any production code for weeks.

They also knew that optimising for speed inevitably means making mistakes.

To counterbalance this, they:

• Celebrated the first time someone broke something with a funny email to the whole engineering team

• Invested heavily in their ability to catch and bounce back from mistakes (e.g. resilience testing, incident response, and monitoring)

In a nutshell:
1. Embrace a culture of speed
2. Build safeguards to maintain it

Facebook's motto at the time?

“Move fast and break things”

How to accomplish more by focusing on less.

'Atomic Habits' is the world’s most comprehensive guide on habit formation.

Here’s a brief, no-fluff summary of the most important and actionable ideas in the book:

𝟭. 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗜𝘁 𝗢𝗯𝘃𝗶𝗼𝘂𝘀: 
Identify a habit you want to start. Place visible reminders around your environment. For instance, if you want to start reading more, leave a book on your pillow each morning after making your bed.

𝟮. 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗜𝘁 𝗔𝘁𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲: 
Combine a habit you need to do with one you want to do. For example, if you want to exercise but love watching TV, allow yourself to watch your favourite show only while working out.

𝟯. 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗜𝘁 𝗘𝗮𝘀𝘆: 
Simplify your new habit. If you're trying to eat healthier, prepare a week’s worth of healthy snacks on Sunday, so you have easy access to them throughout the week.

𝟰. 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗜𝘁 𝗦𝗮𝘁𝗶𝘀𝗳𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴: 
Reward yourself immediately after doing your new habit. If you’ve just completed a workout, treat yourself to a relaxing sauna. 

𝟱. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗧𝘄𝗼-𝗠𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘁𝗲 𝗥𝘂𝗹𝗲: 
Break down your habits into tasks that can be started in under two minutes. If you want to practice an instrument daily, start with just playing for two minutes, and you’ll inevitably continue for longer. 

𝟲. 𝗛𝗮𝗯𝗶𝘁 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴: 
Link a new habit to an existing one. After brushing your teeth (existing habit), immediately do two minutes of meditation (new habit).

𝟳. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗟𝗮𝘄 𝗼𝗳 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝗘𝗳𝗳𝗼𝗿𝘁: 
Arrange your environment to support your new habits. If you’re trying to stop doom-scrolling late at night, leave your phone outside of your bedroom. 

𝟴. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗼𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗸𝘀 𝗥𝘂𝗹𝗲: 
Habits should be neither too hard nor too easy. If you're learning a language, don’t try to read a complex novel right away; start with a simple article.

𝟵. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗙𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝘆 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗙𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗱𝘀: 
Share your goals with friends or family. Join or create a group where members hold each other accountable for their habits, like a book club.

𝟭𝟬. 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗛𝗮𝗯𝗶𝘁𝘀: 
Keep a habit tracker to make progress visible and keep you motivated.

𝟵. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗥𝗼𝗹𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗙𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝘆 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗙𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗱𝘀: 
Share your goals with friends or family. Join or create a group where members hold each other accountable for their habits, like a book club.

𝟭𝟬. 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗛𝗮𝗯𝗶𝘁𝘀: 
Keep a habit tracker to make progress visible and keep you motivated. This could be a simple calendar where you mark each day you complete your habit or an app that helps you monitor your progress.

13 pieces of advice for someone starting their strategy career: 
 
1. Learn to write. In practice, strategies that aren’t documented don’t exist. 
2. Understand game theory and cognitive biases in buyer psychology. 
3. Get used to sparring. The winning ideas are the ones with 'buy-in'. 
4. Dissect case studies of successful AND unsuccessful strategies. 
5. Study the 100-year companies (eg. Coca-Cola, Target, Boeing). 
6. Learn storytelling. Make your recommendations memorable. 
7. Apply the Pyramid Principle - always put the answer first. 
8. Get comfortable with analytics and financial modelling. 
9. Understand tradeoffs and prioritisation frameworks. 
10. Read more newsletters + blogs than social media. 
11. Prioritise listening and asking great questions. 
12. Practice “5 Whys” to discover the root cause. 
13. Always start with the customer problem.

3x cognitive biases Apple uses to make you spend more:

Let's say you want to buy an iPad. 

You open the Apple website, and you're presented with 5x options:

𝟭. $𝟯𝟮𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝟵𝘁𝗵 𝗚𝗲𝗻): The most affordable iPad.
𝟮. $𝟰𝟰𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝟭𝟬𝘁𝗵 𝗚𝗲𝗻): The newer iPad with a better display, chip, camera, and USB-C.
𝟯. $𝟰𝟵𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝗠𝗶𝗻𝗶): The compact iPad that fits in one hand. 
𝟰. $𝟱𝟵𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝗔𝗶𝗿): The thinner and lighter iPad with a laptop-grade chip. 
𝟱. $𝟳𝟵𝟵 (𝗶𝗣𝗮𝗱 𝗣𝗿𝗼): The best iPad money can buy.

Like most prospective customers, your needs would be met with the cheapest iPad on offer...

but you end up spending an additional 82% (+$270) on the iPad Air. 

Why is that?

The answer begins with the
👉 “𝗖𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿-𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗘𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁” 👈

When customers are presented with a range of choices, they perceive the middle options to be the 𝘣𝘦𝘴𝘵 𝘷𝘢𝘭𝘶𝘦-𝘧𝘰𝘳-𝘮𝘰𝘯𝘦𝘺.

Most buyers don’t consider themselves a 𝘱𝘰𝘸𝘦𝘳-𝘶𝘴𝘦𝘳 needing a ‘Pro’ device.

But there’s also natural aversion to buying a 𝘱𝘳𝘦𝘷𝘪𝘰𝘶𝘴-𝘨𝘦𝘯 device.

Due to the 👉 “𝗖𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿-𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗘𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁” 👈, you’re likely to initiate your purchase flow with the base 10th Gen iPad.

After choosing a colour, you’re asked to “Choose how much space you’ll need”:
64GB or 256GB.

For 4x the storage, it’s just an extra $150. 

One scroll later, you must “Choose how you’ll stay connected”:
Wi-Fi only, or Wi-Fi + Cellular.

Again, another $150.

Each upsell is introduced one-by-one, taking up the entire viewport, rather than all at once to gauge them holistically.

As you assess each incremental upsell, 
🔄 "𝗖𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 𝗕𝗶𝗮𝘀" 🔄 stops you from reverting decisions you previously committed to.

Whether you picked extra storage or cellular connectivity, it won’t take long to realise that the extra $150 could instead cover upgrading to the iPad Air. 

⚓️ "𝗔𝗻𝗰𝗵𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗕𝗶𝗮𝘀" ⚓️ makes you calibrate the $150 price tag to the 𝘷𝘢𝘭𝘶𝘦 of the storage and cellular add-ons.

If you want to do creative projects but never have the energy, try this:

Nature is more than just a backdrop for relaxation; it actively enhances our creative thinking and problem-solving abilities.

Getting out into nature with a clear aim to do creative work as a massively underrated tool.

Here’s my protocol for an intentional day of personal projects:

→ 𝗠𝗼𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗥𝗼𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗲
Begin your morning by stepping outside. Feel the natural elements (the sun, a breeze, the texture of grass). Just a couple of minutes can really clear the mind, calibrate your senses, and sharpen focus.

→ 𝗦𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀
Carry a notebook and pen on a short walk in a nearby park or natural setting, away from digital distractions. Write down a maximum of 3 things you’d like to focus on. Put a star next to the one that is your highest priority - the one that, once completed, would make the day a success.

→ 𝗝𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗮𝗹
To get the creative juices flowing, handwrite down a short answer to each of these prompts:
• Describe your natural surroundings.
• What’s 1 trait you want to exhibit today?
• What’s 1 thing you’re grateful for?

→ 𝗗𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸
Curate a workspace with natural elements (e.g., plants, natural light, open windows for fresh air). The more minimal and distraction-free, the better. Brew your hot beverage of choice, take a deep breath, and start your day with a 2-hour uninterrupted block focussed on your highest priority task.

→ 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺𝗶𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘄𝗮𝗹𝗸𝘀
Introduce short, regular walking breaks in your routine, preferably in natural, green spaces. Experiment with different levels of stimulus: Notebook, no notebook. Music, no music. Use this time for reflection or pondering creative challenges, letting the natural environment stimulate new perspectives.

→ 𝗪𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗱𝗼𝘄𝗻
As daylight shifts to dusk, allow your mind to naturally transition to relaxation. Under soft lighting, jot down any lingering thoughts or reflections in a journal. Close the cognitive chapter on productivity, and enjoy an evening of leisurely reading, cooking, and resting.

North Star Metrics 101

My Mum texted me recently asking, “What’s a North Star Metric?” 

Here’s what I sent her:

So you’ve built a product, and people are using it. 

You start tracking everything you can to measure how well the product is performing:

- Daily/Weekly/Monthly Active Users
- Customer Acquisition Cost
- Customer growth rate
- Net expansion rate
- Conversion rate
- Feature usage
- Lifetime value
- Contraction
- Retention
- Drop-off

Invariably, you run into the same problem: 

You want all key metrics to go up, but you’re not sure which ones to prioritise investing in.

The answer?

The North Star Metric: A single metric that defines success for your business. 

“Wouldn’t that just be revenue?”

Although it’s tempting to always default to financial KPIs, the best North Star Metrics help businesses understand how customers truly derive value from their product. 

Put simply - the more you drive your North Star, the more 𝙫𝙖𝙡𝙪𝙚 your business creates.

How Loom uses local network effects to drive a viral user growth flywheel: 

When users send a video message via Loom, any receiver can view the Loom and send a reply.

In other words, even non-users experience fast time-to-value.

“Video messaging” saves everyone a meeting, can be watched at 2x speed, and lets recipients jump around to focus on relevant topics.

When they finish the video, they see:
(a) a message congratulating them for saving time, and
(b) a prompt to sign up.

Because Looms are inherently shareable within an organisation, employees become net promoters of the tool 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗯𝘆 𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘁. 

Similar to the “invite a friend” mechanic that built many of today’s tech giants.

Employees without a license end up signing up for one organically.

Even with only a handful of initial signups, over time, companies end up becoming a 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘂𝘀𝗲𝘀 𝗟𝗼𝗼𝗺.

Steve Jobs had a simple rule for designing the perfect user interface:

The 3-click rule.

Steve was intimately involved in the design and development of the original iPod.

Those that knew him said he had the same response to nearly every problem -

“Simplify!”

During product demos, he would go over every screen and apply a rigid test:

If a user wants to use a core feature (eg play a song) ...

they must be able to get there in three clicks.

The success of the iPod changed the industry forever, and the 3-click rule quickly spread across product development circles.

Airbnb founder Brian Chesky was always adamant users are never more than 3 clicks away from a booking.

Same as reading trending content from your favourite subreddit.

Or watching your favourite Youtuber’s latest video.

If you're building a consumer product, ask yourself:

How many clicks does it take for a user to reach your unique-selling-point?

DoorDash pulled off one of the most underappreciated market share robberies of all time.

In just 3 years, they exploded from 16% to 53% share of the US delivery app market.

Here’s 4 strategies they used to crush Uber Eats, GrubHub and Postmates:

1. Avoiding the competition

DoorDash targeted restaurants without delivery services, often with pre-existing customer bases, rather than competing for newer restaurants with multiple other providers. 

2. Empowering restaurants

DoorDash acquired restaurants by providing them with not just delivery services, but insights they never had before: popular dishes in the area, customer demographics, local delivery times, and more.

3. Maximising AOV

DoorDash focussed on winning outer suburbs with large family homes - an underserved segment with a much higher average-order-value (AOV) than urban regions.

4. Brand positioning

When Covid hit, DoorDash supported its Dashers and restaurants by offering payment advances and other benefits, creating significant supply growth for their marketplace.

Doordash saw the opportunity, developed a plan... and they delivered.

SEO 101:


People looking to design something don’t search for an ‘all-in-one design solution’.

They start a business, decide they need a logo, and search ‘Logo Maker’.

A few sales meetings later, they search ‘Free Business Card Maker’.

Canva, maker of the world’s favourite ‘all-in-one design solution’, knows this.

So - they built hundreds of landing pages for specific design tools that prospects are actively searching for.

Unlike their front page, which is probably swamped with low-intent evaluators, Canva’s utility-focussed lead magnets capture highly convertible leads wanting to land in-product as quickly as possible.

Throughout the journey, users are subtle introduced to the universe of premium design possibilities available on the platform.

Enticing tooltips, gated features, teamwork capabilities, and free AI credits all systematically funnel free users towards the paid offering.

Canva’s strategy in one line:

“Make stuff people search for” — Harry Dry

Back in May 2008, Steve Jobs personally approved the text iPhone users would see when they sideload an app.

Why this is fascinating:

• It means that Apple had contemplated how third party apps should be sideloaded onto iOS - something that is still not allowed by Apple 15 years later.

•  Furthermore, Apple had actually designed and built a prototype for this feature.

• Steve Jobs personally provided input into relatively minor language decisions in Apple software.

• Steve Jobs’s preference was the “simpler” language option that drew less attention to the fact that the app “did not come from the App Store”.

• This all took place behind the scenes 1 year after the iPhone was released (increasing Apple’s valuation by +33%) and the same year as the release of the App Store.

• The initial email was sent by iOS chief Scott Forstall just 2 months after declaring that “the App Store is going to be the exclusive way to distribute iPhone applications”.

Source: This email is one of many internal emails and confidential presentations unearthed during the legal discovery process in the Epic v. Apple case around App Store fairness.

💬 What are your takeaways from reading this email?

Snapchat could be the most underappreciated tech acquirer of all time.

When you break it down, their entire business is an amalgamation of acquired startups.

Here are the 25 deals that shaped the Snapchat of today:

1. AddLive (2014) - $30m
Became Snapchats ‘Video Chat’ feature.

2. Vergence Labs (2014) - $15m
Became ‘Spectacles’, Snapchat’s smart glasses hardware line.

3. Scan me (2014) - $50m
Became ‘Snapcodes’, Snapchat’s personalised QR code feature.

4. Looksery (2015) - $150m
Became ‘Filters’ and ‘Lenses’, Snapchat’s facial recognition and modification technology.

5. Bitstrips (2016) - $100m
Became ‘Bitmojis’, Snapchat’s personalised avatars.

6. Seene (2016) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s ‘3D Selfies’, powering face swaps and other AR overlays.

7. Vurb (2016) - $114.5m
Became Snapchat’s local business search and discovery features.

8. Flite (2016) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s tech powering 360° video ads and vertical video ads.

9. Cimagine (2016) - $30-40m
Became Snapchat’s AR product visualisation features.

10. Ctrl Me Robotics (2017) - <$1m
Became part of Snapchat’s hardware team.

11. Placed (2017) - $135m
Became Snapchat’s ad tracking for foot traffic and conversions in physical stores.

12. Zenly (2017) - $213m
Became ‘Snap Map’, Snapchat’s interactive social maps.

13. Strong Codes (2017) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s code protection technology.

14. Metamarkets (2017) - $100m
Became Snapchat’s analytics dashboard for advertisers.

15. PlayCanvas (2018) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s ‘Lens Studio’, where developers build AR Lens effects.

16. Teleport (2018) - $8m
Became part of Snapchat’s ‘Filters’ technology, powering features like hair colour changes.

17. AIFactory (2020) - $166m
Became ‘Cameos’, Snapchat’s animated selfie video feature.

18. Voca ai (2020) - $70m
Became Snapchat’s Ai-based voice agents for customer support.

19. Voisey (2020) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s music creation and sharing features.

20. Ariel AI (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s AR experiences team.

21. Fit Analytics (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s virtual clothing try-on and sizing features.

22. Screenshop (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became Snapchat’s product recommendations based on images saved to ‘Memories’.

23. Demand Sage (2021) - Undisclosed amount
Became part of Snapchat’s ad reporting and analytics features.

24. Pixel8earth (2021) - $7.6m
Became part of ‘Local Lenses’, Snapchat’s location-based AR experiences.

25. WaveOptics (2021) - $500m
Became Snapchat’s AR display manufacturing team.

The flipside — to use them, you had to:
• Pay a multi-thousand-dollar fixed fee upfront
• Install locally on a high-spec machine

Today is Google's 25th birthday.

But if you use Google Search to find things online, you’re wasting your time.

The most underrated way to find anything worthwhile online:

Use Reddit - not Google.

Why?

Let’s say you want to buy some new headphones.

You're looking to identify best-in-class products, so you head to Google Search.

The Search Engine Results Page (SERP) is likely a mix of:
• Pay-per-click ads
• ‘People Also Ask’ accordions
• Direct-to-consumer headphones stores
• ‘Top 10 wireless headphones’ affiliate blogs

In other words, you aren’t being shown best-in-class products.

You are simply being shown:
• Merchants paying to be on top of your SERP
• Content farms using Q&A to optimise SERP placement
• Stores with the best Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) ranking
• Affiliate marketing blogs taking commission for recommending products

➔ Important note:

You MAY discover best-in-class products on Google.

But you won’t discover them on Google BECAUSE they are the best.

By definition, you will only discover them because they had the best Adwords / SEO / affiliate strategy to rank on the keywords you searched. 

Now let’s look at Reddit.

Reddit is where people who obsess about specific niches go to discuss that niche.

If you head to r/headphones, r/headphoneadvice, or r/audiophile, you’re experience will look something like:
✔️ A crowd-sourced ‘ultimate buying guide’ based on years of contributions
✔️ Long reviews from people who compulsively buy and test every top-tier model
✔️ Monthly megathreads where headphone enthusiasts debate the pros and cons of new releases
✔️ Bar charts ranking all major headphones by the number of times they are mentioned in that subreddit
✔️ ‘10 things I wish I knew before I bought…’ / ‘Make sure you do this before you buy…’ / ‘My favourite pair after 10 years of…’

Better yet, the most valuable content (in the eyes of a collective of headphone fanatics) is surfaced to the top thanks to the upvote mechanism.

Once it clicks that you can outsource your research / discovery / analysis to Reddit for just about anything, it feels like a superpower.

Hope this helps!

This maths teacher from rural Australia just sold his tech company for $40m.

From bootstrapped side hustle to life-changing exit.

Here is Andrew Spitty’s incredible story:

In 2011, Andrew was teaching at Kerang Technical High School in a small town in country Victoria.

Frustrated by inconsistencies in how students were assessed across schools, he saw an opportunity:

Provide schools with a standardised set of numeracy and literacy assessments, and software that tracks how well students and schools perform.

He launched ‘Essential Assessment’ in 2012 as a side hustle.

Besides contracting his brother Troy to build the basic website and solution, Andrew was a solo operator for the first 4 years.

Working as the only salesperson, customer service, marketer, business manager, content developer (and a full-time maths teacher) he grew his customer-base to over 500 schools (!!)

In 2015, Andrew had proven his business had momentum to scale, and decided to go all-in.

He brought his brother on full-time, scaled the company to 22 employees, and expanded to over 2500 schools in the next 7 years.

Today, more than a third of primary schools in Victoria and NSW use Essential Assessment to assess student performance and improve achievement.

So, how did the acquisition come about?

New Zealand-based ‘Education Perfect’, a digital teaching and learning toolkit for schools, saw a natural strategic alignment between the two companies.

“Essential Assessment is incredibly strong in primary schools, while we are absolutely the market leader in middle school and moving into senior, and we saw this wonderful fit ... also in culture, with a very strong focus on teachers” — Helen Souness, chair of Education Perfect’s board.

From a product synergy perspective, the partnership also showed great potential: “Three key things for us is that we’re saving teachers time, we are able to assess students and give insights on their progress, and then use that to give personalised learning pathways.”

When it’s all said and done, Andrew Smitty will walk away from this deal with ~$40m in cash.

100% shareholder. No outside investment. Profitable since year 1. Fully bootstrapped.

Trust the maths teacher to run the numbers.

At an executive retreat at Jeff Bezos’ house in 2003, Amazon leadership ran an exercise that changed the course of history forever. 

The exercise started with a discussion about Amazon's core competencies:

→ Offering a broad selection of products? 
→ Check.

→ Fulfilling and shipping orders? 
→ Nailing it.

A few rotations later, they discussed IT.

As a rapidly-scaling low-margin retail business, they had been forced to become market-leaders in running reliable and cost-effective state-of-the-art data centres.

This little nugget presented an opportunity: 

In 1900, a business had to build a generator to open a shop, so why should a business in 2000 have to build its own datacenter?

Over the next few years, Amazon folded its highly-desirable architecture inside-out, offering compute, databases, and storage to the market under the banner ‘Amazon Web Services’.

The result?

Today AWS services 41.5% (!!) of all web application workloads.

While it accounts for 13% of $AMZN’s revenue, it pulls in nearly 75% of the company’s operating profit.

Square co-founder Jim McKelvey built their first card-reader prototype by hand.

A timeless lesson in thinking outside the box:

Back in 2010, the only approved way to connect any piece of hardware to an iPhone was through the dock connector.

Apple had a lengthy and expensive approval process to use the connector, special chipsets you had to use, royalties on each unit, and many other restrictions.

On the other hand, every phone on the market, not just the iPhone, had a microphone jack.

But the jack was only designed to take an audio signal.

Jim knew that the audio software developer kit was part of the public iPhone libraries and therefore didn’t need Apple’s permission to use.

He and co-founder Jack Dorsey devised a way to make the data on a credit card stripe appear to be the output of a microphone.

By using the microphone jack to circumvent Apple’s dock connector rules, they had a working prototype in a week.

The takeaway here?

When building your MVP, it’s better to ask for forgiveness than permission!
